@@ -1,1 +198,202 @@    ```bash
    manifest-tool inspect --raw gcr.io/k8s-staging-e2e-test-images/${IMAGE_NAME}:${VERSION} | jq '.[0].Digest'

comments.body: pretty sure these also build on macOS?

I was able to use Docker for Mac for agnhost:2.1 - 2.3, though I had to comment out https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/test/images/image-util.sh#L91 

I have been able to get away with this because Docker for Mac provides `binfmt_misc` support out of the box https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-mac/multi-arch/
So, should we add an ``if !macOS`` to the line mentioned by @spiffxp and add macOS here as well?
I think so

is recommended in order to avoid certain issues.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +39,43 @@creating an entirely separate test image.

Some test images (`mounttest`, `test-webserver`) are used as bases for other images (`mounttest-user`,
`kitten`, `nautilus`). If the parent image's `VERSION` has been bumped, also bump the version in the
children's `BASEIMAGE` files in order for base image changes to be reflected in the child images as well.

@@ -1,1 +53,57 @@## Building images

The images are built through `make`. Since some images (`mounttest`, `test-webserver`)
are used as a base for other images, it is recommended to build them first, if needed.

comments.body: I think we should find a way to rewrite this test to use an image that is updated less frequently than agnhost for this test so we don't have to push to two repos

We could. The test basically uses `/agnhost serve-hostname`, and checks the hostname of every pod in the replica set by proxying into the pod and doing a GET.

We could just use the other images in the authenticated registry (alpine:3.7, windows-nanoserver:v1) and exec ``hostname`` into the pods to get the same results. This will have to be done in another PR IMO. Thoughts?
+1, I think there's another authenticated registry with small infrequently updated images right?

comments.body: Can you be more explicit about why this version is preferred?
Hm, there's no particular reason why it has to be 18.06.0 or newer on the Windows nodes. 18.06.0 or newer was chosen for consistency with the requirements on the Linux node (see L11).
most build things are 19.03 by now

comments.body: Line 14: s/In order to build the docker test images, a Linux node is required./In order to build the docker test Linux container images, a Linux node is required./
Unrelated to the PR, and it's still correct: you do need a Linux node to build *all* images. With this PR, you'll be able to also build Windows images remotely, but you do it from the Linux node.
